thread.title: Can Turnbull turn innovation rhetoric into reality?
thread.title_full: Can Turnbull turn innovation rhetoric into reality? | Business Spectator

author: Antonluigi Gozzi
title: Can Turnbull turn innovation rhetoric into reality?
text:
Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull has put innovation back on the nation’s agenda, but will he be able to put it into practice?
We live in a fantastic period of technological innovation and opportunity, but our political class has shown itself to be stuck in the era of typewriters so often in recent years.
There is at last cause for hope under the leadership of Turnbull, who has so far highlighted the importance of innovation, education and R&D to his agenda.
But we need more than slogans and promises to turn the country’s fortunes around. We need practical solutions to make those ideas a reality.
I would like to outline what I see as the three basic building blocks for encouraging technological innovation and success - entrepreneurship, agility and education - and examples of how the government could embrace them.
Entrepreneurship is the outcome of a culture where investment is welcomed, incentivised and rewarded.
The government can help to foster such a culture by reducing the perceived risk of investment. The sensible way to do that is to provide risk capital.
There are two forms of risk capital, one longer term, such as R&D funding, and a second one more immediate - co-investing in start-up innovation, whatever the sector.
We have literally fallen to the bottom of the list of OECD countries in terms of investing in R&D as a percentage of GDP.
We must ask ourselves - why aren't Australian businesses investing in R&D? Why do we have the lowest investment in high-tech manufacturing, even as our manufacturing industry is being decimated?
Until this is reversed, our firms will never be competitive outside our national (and protected) borders.
When it comes to investment in start-ups, the government should be matching or even bettering private funds. It is not a crazy idea. It is good policy.
In Israel, the government puts in $7 for every $1 of private investment in a start-up. That means 85 per cent of investment in tech risk capital comes from the government.
The result is that Israel saw a $25 billion growth in exports, and a high return on its investment.
Now let me apply that thinking to a real-life example closer to home.
I believe the Department of Employment is looking for new software to manage unemployment services, and its budget for the project is between $2 and 3 billion.
Rather than paying that money to an overseas company to provide an “off the shelf” service which is modified to fit the Australian system, we could use it to develop our own from scratch.
That sort of money could employ 10,000 IT professionals on $100,000 a year for three years and result in a better final outcome.
It would be an investment that would foster Australia’s technology ecosystem and build on IP knowledge created by Australians for the rest of the world, not the other way around.
The second building block is agility, a word we are hearing more and more of in business and political conversations. But what does it actually mean?
Put simply, agility means adapting and innovating on the fly. It means making continuous small, incremental improvements, experimenting and adopting a “now, not later” approach.
What the federal government, the highest IT spender in Australia, would need to do to support agility in business is trust companies to iterate and adapt on the job.
Smaller companies which do not meet all the requirements for a government contract may be able to evolve to meet them and implement the necessary protocols as the job progresses.
In fact, the government could even help them do it.
Imagine if the government’s approach to awarding tenders was not to swamp applicants in red tape, but ask them what support they needed to succeed?
Such an approach could breed an unprecedented amount of engagement between government and business and lead to opportunities we haven’t even imagined yet.
Finally, the last building block we need is one of the most obvious and important - education.
Australia has a shortage of workers skilled in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM), the area in which it needs them them the most.
To fix this problem in the short term, we must come up with a way to attract as much talent from overseas as we can in the fields of engineering, coding and IT.
Fixing the skills shortage problem will need investment in teaching our children the skills they will need to succeed in the 21st century.
Some steps toward this goal were made this month, with the endorsement of the new Digital Technologies curriculum at a federal level. The curriculum will hopefully see all children introduced to technical and coding skills at an early age if it is adopted by the states.
But the government also needs to invest in more IT-focused international exchange programs for tertiary students with countries such as China, Singapore, Hong Kong, Japan and the US.
Just one of the students who embarked on such a program could go on to create the next Uber or Facebook. That alone would be worth it.
To some people, these ideas may sound like blue-sky thinking. But that’s because our national debate has been so backwards for so long.
These things are already happening right now in other nations which are embracing the building blocks of technological success - entrepreneurship, agility and education - and will also reap the benefits.
Will Australia join them? I certainly hope so.
Antonluigi “Gigi” Gozzi is the co-founder and Managing Director of online labour marketplace LiveHire.
